author: {'steamid': '76561198082764480', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 427, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1691914362}
review:
Toast Time is a game where you try to fend of enemies from an alarm clock by shooting breads. You move the opposite direction of where you shoot which makes up for a very awkward and hard to control gameplay.
I tried to give it a fair shot and played it for a while but i can't see myself finishing the game for multiple reasons.
The game is literally a mobile game. Not even a proper port, ui and aspect ratio is not suited for pc. This game might be a fun time killer on mobile but i can't see any reason why someone would want to play this instead of tons of other great games on steam. Related to that also is the controls feeling off and imprecise. Your character is very bouncy which results in an uncontrollable rage game especially on later levels where you have to stay on the ground to protect the clock.
I probably got it in a bundle and wanted to check it out but i would advise you against buying it or playing it since it is just a very basic time-killer.

review:
[quote]Follow my Curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41363546-Fruit-N-Doggie-Reviews/]Fruit N Doggie Reviews,[/url] so you can be updated whenever I post a new review.[/quote]
[h1]Overall Rating - Seriously Flawed â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†â˜†[/h1]

[h1]First Impressions[/h1]
My sense for the quality of Steam titles was quite low initially, so I didn't realize that I probably wasn't going to be a fan of Toast Time (TT) when it showed up in a bundle. A simple, yet fun game about blasting enemies with toast sounds kind of odd. It could have been pretty enjoyable too, but there's a few key issues that really hinders the experience. 


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
There's two game modes available in TT. The first are referred to as Missions, and after clearing enough of those stages, you'll unlock Survival Mode. Most of the missions are solely focused on keeping the enemies from making contact with the clock, as you wait out the timer until enough time has passed. While shooting at the enemies with your projectile, crates will occasionally spawn in, giving you one of the weapons that you've currently unlocked. The more crates you obtain, the more options that will be available. Unfortunately, what weapon you're given is completely random, instead of being pre-set to better match the layout or situation. Picking up a crate might give you the perfect weapon, or something that's nigh worthless. Occasionally, a mission will have a unique effect in place, such as limiting how many shots you can fire.

What I find odd about the game is Survival Mode, also known as Iron Man Mode. As you might expect, it's set up as a gauntlet, where you have to clear every stage without failure. Any mistakes forces the player to start over from scratch again. None of that is unusual, but you unlock this mode long before you finish every stage. I'd think the sensible thing to do would be to open this option after clearing each stage, as an additional challenge. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3158066937
[h1]Controls[/h1]
This was one of the areas in the game that I found unsatisfactory. Shooting at enemies causes immense recoil to your character, and when you're firing on multiple foes, you'll wind up flying all over the screen. Just keeping up with the enemies spawning into the stage can be difficult, but with this affecting your place on the screen and sometimes putting barriers between the enemies and where you want to shoot, it's a significant burden. It's the equivalent of a 3D shooter, but one where you don't have direct control over your position on the map, because each gunshot propels you around instead. That'd be a nightmare, and it's no better here.


[h1]Story[/h1]
Because this is an arcade experience, there isn't any plot behind being a living toaster fighting sentient... water? They look like drops of rain and icicles, but I'm not really positive. Then again, everyone knows how water is a toaster's greatest enemy, so I'm guessing that'd be the logic here. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3158066229
[h1]Visuals[/h1]
I'll give the game some credit, for being able to make cute sprites out of a title that makes use of so few colors at any time. Unfortunately, the developers weren't more considerate for the side effect this would lead to. When the screen gets busy, it's very difficult to distinguish one thing from another, because all the crucial elements are the same color: your projectiles, the clock, your own character sprite, and of course the enemies. Even if they just changed the projectiles and enemies to different colors, I think it'd help quite a bit. Ironically enough, the background has a gradient effect, so it'll subtly change from one color to the next, while all the crucial objects are all white.


[h1]Sound Design[/h1]
From what I noticed, the songs are played in a random order, or at least aren't specific to the stage or set of missions you're currently on. They don't seem to end in time for the stage wrapping up, which isn't too surprising with how short each one is. Any given one might last for 35 or less seconds, so the tunes don't get much time to get anywhere. I have to think that continuously playing the songs that'd continue despite a stage ending or you failing would work better with these limitations. The short refrain that plays out after beating a stage is enjoyable enough.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3158066679
[h1]Pros[/h1]
ğŸŒŸ Honestly, I love the lighthearted and silly premise this game has. Arcade games don't have to be gritty and realistic to be engaging, they can be cute and silly.
ğŸŒŸ Power-ups drop into the stage, helping to even the odds against the merciless, smiling enemies. 


[h1]Cons[/h1]
âŒ Once you see the orientation of the game on your PC, you'll figure out that this was originally a mobile game that was ported over. TT isn't too outrageously priced, but I think it has enough issues that it should be on the cheaper side. 
âŒ There's an achievement for playing this title for just under six hours, yet it's rarely earned. The game also has cards, which would lead to many people grinding for the unlocks, and hasn't bumped this up to even 2%. 
âŒ The mechanics don't work in solidarity with each other, making for a frustrating experience.


[h1]Tips[/h1]
ğŸ” If a power-up generates in an out of the way place, it's probably not worth getting, since you may not be able to get back into place in time.
ğŸ” Firing at enemies with intention seems to be the best approach. Spamming attacks without regard for anything won't always work.


[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
There's a few areas in games that will almost always cause problems, and TT includes two of them. First of all, the controls make the game much more difficult than it needs to be, as firing on the enemies flings you around the screen. It feels punishing when that's the only option you have to fight back, aside from crashing into the ground near them. Although a different problem, the lack of color and distinction between your projectiles and the enemies leads to a similar outcome. When you have a hard time telling what's happening, it comes across as unfair, which is how the lack of control over your own character feels. Despite the cute, silly premise, playing this game isn't nearly as fun as it might look, so I wouldn't recommend it.

A greatly underrated little game with amazingly energetic music.

Basically a shooter, you use the mouse to aim at silly little smiling monsters who are trying to break your alarm clock.  Your guy Terry isn't hurt by monsters himself, but wherever he fires, he's flung in the opposite direction.  At first this isn't much of an issue, but it isn't too far in where you're having to choose your shots carefully to stop your heroic slice of toast from getting hurled behind barriers and unable to hit his grinning foes.  Additionally crates fall from the sky; shooting one gives Terry a random powerup from all those unlocked.  Some of these require quite a bit of skill to use, but others fill the screen in a gratifying spray of breakfast ordinance.

Additionally, each level rates you on the now-traditional three star scale.  Getting that third star in later levels can become a heroic undertaking.  Sometimes it feels as if the third star, on certain levels, requires getting a specific powerup, which is a bit tiring.  Still though, it is a fun little game that's worth a few dollars at least, and has been nearly invisible in terms of promotion.  It's worth a look!

review:
Toast Time is a retro shooter with a twist. It looks quite hectic as player invulnerable player character is bouncing around the screen. 

Bouncing around actually is big part of the challenge. Obiously shooting is means to kill enemies, but it's also is only way to move. So while shooting, it's also important to pay attention where player character is actually going. In later levels it's usually some place that's hard to get out from and somewhere that's doesn't have access to clock that needs to be defended. 

Levels have different twists, which keeps gameplay varied. Also there's unlockable guns (or bread, it's Toast Time after all). 

But all in all, Toast Time has best of the retro game qualities, frustrating, but still very addictive. Give it a try.

review:
What is Toast Time?

A bloody good little game! That's what. 
[url]http://youtu.be/PWR3DBJLEH8[/url]

Get hyped up on coffee and go save breakfast from evil little buggers, that want to do nothing more than to deprive you of your syrupy dripping noms first thing in the morning.

In it, you're Terry. A rapid firing toast launching toaster, that needs to save the best meal of the day. 
The entire game is controlled via the mouse, once you fire a slice you're hurled back by the force of the recoil. Which you can then use to navigate the little map to ensure you can dispose of the breakfast crashing buggers!

Like doughnuts? SURE, fire a bajillion of them at whatever the hell those evil little things are. French toast, bagels, baguettes, and more! Just lob them all over over the place, and protect that little alarm clock.

The graphics might be the pinnacle of old school, but it complements the game perfectly, and the music is outstanding. 
Toast time, is simply fun. Pure fun, condensed into silliness, and I enjoy it.

It's easy to overlook the direct port, with just added mouse controls; as the game is still in portrait mode. It simply doesn't matter due to have addictive and fun the little game can be.

I would heartily recommend this to anyone that just wants some toast filled fun. Even more so if you want to get it on a mobile device.

You can do this by shooting bread at them and itâ€™s done with the press of a mouse button. Simple. But, thereâ€™s something else you have to take into account. By shooting bread you will also thrust yourself into the opposite direction. It makes for some stressful situations as more and more enemies approach the clock and by missing just one shot you can risk losing the game entirely. Fortunately for us the levels are short and can be finished within several seconds to several minutes, max. Restarting them takes only a few seconds and after that youâ€™re on your way again. â€˜Just one more timeâ€™ is what youâ€™ll be saying time and time again, because of the way the game (re)loads levels so quickly. Well played, Toast Time. Well played.
The clock functions as some sort of base, by the way, and if only one enemy bumps into it you will fail the level. Itâ€™s absolutely necessary to protect it. A difficult task, but made easier with your (unlockable) weapons, which brings me to the following point:
Collecting boxes during your playthrough allows you to unlock a new random weapon (of the collection that you already own) that might make your objective easier. For every x amount of boxes you collect youâ€™ll unlock a new weapon. Some of them are useful, others are, erm, less useful, depending on the situation of course. There are also cosmetic items to unlock like a monocle or a tophat. Funny stuff, but not really needed for a single-player game except to give the character more personality.

Graphically Toast Time uses a retro look. Its graphics reminded me a bit of Meat Boy, or any other game designed by Edward McMillen. The older generation I mean. Since the game was originally made with mobile phones in mind the game is also shown as a full screen rectangle (i.e. like the screen of a mobile phone) with borders on the sides that show off a bit of the environment. It works fine and it isnâ€™t annoying or distracting.
Sound wise the game is basic. The music is cheery and up tempo and the sound effects like shooting projectiles or smashing into the ground are satisfying. I donâ€™t think the sound effects couldâ€™ve been any better to be honest, even if they are so basic. They just fit the style and nature of the game.

I think that finishing Toast Time will take at least several hours, Iâ€™m not sure yet, as I havenâ€™t been able to complete all the levels yet. Some of them are just so frustratingly hard, and a few of them also require a bit of luck. But like I said, itâ€™s fun for short sessions. Donâ€™t play this non-stop.
